introduction.p: For Problems 12, write the complex number in the form a+bi, where a and b are real numbers.
For Problems 36, find the zeros of the quadratic polynomial. Write each zero in the form a+bi, where a and b are real numbers.
For Problems 35-40, evaluate the polynomial for the given values of the variable.
For Problems 4146, expand the product of polynomials.
For Problems 4750, plot the number and its complex conjugate in the complex plane. What is the geometric relationship between complex conjugates?
For Problems 5154, sketch the set of points in the complex plane.

statement.p: The set of all z=a+bi for which a \ge b
The set of all z=a+bi for which a+b \lt 2

introduction.p: For Problems 5558, illustrate addition using the parallelogram rule in the complex plane.

statement.p: Prove that the product of two complex numbers z_1=a+bi and z_2=c+di is z_1z_2=(a+bi)(c+di) = (ac-bd)+(ad+bc)i

Prove that the quotient of two complex numbers z_1=a+bi and z_2=c+di is \dfrac{z_1}{z_2} = \dfrac{a+bi}{c+di} = \dfrac{a+bi}{c+di} \cdot \dfrac{c-di}{c-di} = \dfrac{ac+bd}{c^2+d^2} + \dfrac{bc-ad}{c^2+d^2}i
Prove the commutative laws for addition and multiplication of complex numbers: z_1+z_2=z_2+z_1 z_1z_2=z_2z_1
Prove the distributive law for complex numbers: z_1(z_2+z_3)=z_1z_2+z_1z_3

ol.li: Show that z+\bar{z} is a real number, and z-\bar{z} is an imaginary number.

statement.p: Suppose t,~ w and z are complex numbers. If w=t+z, is it necessarily true that \abs{w}=\abs{t}+\abs{z}? Provide examples to support your conclusion.

answer.p: No. Let t=i and z=-i. Then w=t+z=i-i=0, so \abs{w}=0, but \abs{t}+\abs{z}=\abs{i}+\abs{-i}=1+1=2.

statement.p: Prove the triangle inequality for complex numbers: \abs{w+z} \le \abs{w}+\abs{z}

introduction.p:
In Problems 6770,
Given one solution of a quadratic equation with rational coefficients, find the other solution.
Write a quadratic equation that has those solutions.
For Problems 7174, find a fourth degree polynomial with real coefficients that has the given complex numbers as two of its zeros.
